1260.3 PORT - 1 FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF SAN FRANCISCO ARCHIVES WORLD WAR II EVACUATION AND RELOCATION PROGRAM RECORDS, PORTLAND BRANCH, 1942 April 5, 2005 Descriptive Summary Title WORLD WAR II EVACUATION AND RELOCATION PROGRAM RECORDS, PORTLAND BRANCH, 1942 Date Range 1942 Collection Number 1260.3 PORT - 1 Creator Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Portland Branch Extent 3 cubic feet (2 boxes, one narrow box, and one flat box) Repository Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Archives 101 Market Street San Francisco, CA 94105 (415) 974-2834 or 974-3217 Shelf Location 2–C–2 Administrative Information Conditions Governing Access The collections are open for research by appointment only Appointments may be made by calling (415) 974-2834 or 974-3217 Accruals This was a one time evacuation. The Portland Branch collection is most likely as complete as we will see, even though some items appear to be missing. The San Francisco collection was microfilmed and the originals were thrown away. That collection will eventually be electronically reconstituted. Language of the Material English OVERVIEW OF THE COLLECTION AND THE FEDERAL RESERVE BANK’S ROLE IN THE EXECUTION OF EXECUTIVE ORDER 9066 On February 19, 1942, President Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066. Under this order, Japanese nationals and Americans of Japanese descent, as well as German and Italian resident aliens, were evacuated and interned during World War II. The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, as fiscal agent of the United States, was designated the agency to assist alien residents of Japanese, Italian, and German origin, and persons of Japanese ancestry in their evacuation. Service center offices were established in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Portland, and Seattle. The War Relocation Authority was established on March 18, 1942, to provide for relocation, maintenance, and supervision of evacuees. The Reserve Bank was to assist evacuees in disposing of property holdings, protect them from fraud, forced sales, and unscrupulous creditors, and arrange for orderly liquidation of business and property interests. Agricultural property and equipment was excluded, as it came under the jurisdiction of the Farm Security Administration. The services of the Reserve Bank were continually available to evacuees; however, they were not compelled to make use of them and were encouraged at all times to make such other arrangements as they might desire with respect to their properties. This collection contains the documents created during the work of the Portland Branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco in fulfilling its role as processor of the properties and goods (other than farms and farm machinery) of Japanese Americans interned during World War II. Following is part of a document outlining the program: The Evacuee Property Department of the Portland Branch, Federal Reserve Bank, was opened on March 13, 1942, at 317 S.W. 6th Ave., Portland, Oregon. The Department was prepared upon its establishment to perform such functions as were outlined in Head Office letter dated March 11, 1942, addressed to Portland Branch. Two regular employees (Mr. Erwin N. Crouch and Mr. S.A. MacEachron ) of the Portland Branch were assigned to the Evacuee Property Department on the opening day. In addition to these, four stenographers and seven consultants were employed on a temporary basis to assist in the performance of such duties as were required. It was not necessary for this branch to maintain permanent field representatives at the various offices of the United States Employment Service. As questions arose involving problems coming within the scope of those handled by the Evacuee Property Department, information was transmitted to the main office at Portland and, when required, field representatives were sent to the localities which requested information or assistance. In other cases problems were settled either by telephone or by correspondence. The Portland newspapers were generous with their publicity regarding activities and duties of the Evacuee Property Department. Out of town newspapers in the Portland zone also gave such publicity as was requested. It was not necessary to exercise freezing control under this Regulation since we had no problems requiring such action. This particular collection contains the documents (originals and/or carbon copies) collected during 1942 by the Portland Branch (Porter Building, 6th and Stark Streets, Portland) as it dealt with individual cases. Box 1 includes an A-Z collection of cases (though the letter of the alphabet sometimes attaches to the family name and sometimes to the business name, so a particular person could be filed in different places). A few of the items are from German citizens, but almost all concern Japanese nationals and US citizens of Japanese descent. Most of the businesses are small and local, such as restaurants, dry cleaners, laundries, plant shops. There are many hotels and farms, the latter being referred to the Farm Security Administration, as mentioned above. Many people wrote immediately to the Federal Reserve, asking what they should do with their possessions and their properties. The Federal Reserve made available free storage for their larger possessions (but the families needed to arrange for their own insurance. Many insurers cancelled their policies on all Japanese clients). There was also outdoor storage made available for automobiles.* The Fed arranged for 24 hour guard service on the storage areas (at a rate not to exceed 85 cents an hour). In spite of this, a large percentage of business owners chose to sell their businesses, frequently at a steep discount. In addition, many were leasing or purchasing properties and had invested money that they didn’t want to lose. Some were able to arrange for non-Japanese citizens to take care of their businesses and keep them running while they were interned, but most had to sell at a discount or board up their properties. The Federal Reserve responded immediately to most of the written requests for help – sometimes the response was dated the day after the original request was made. The courtesy and helpfulness of the personnel in responding to these letters was consistent. The Fed’s role was to help the evacuees with practical problems encountered during the transition. The Fed would indicate the options for storage of large items and in many cases add that the person was also encouraged to make his or her own arrangements if these would be satisfactory. There were several legal actions brought at the time, either regarding existing problems that were now going to be put on hold or concerns about how to collect on debts in the future. Since the internees would not be earning a salary for an indefinite period of time, they would not be able to honor financial commitments for purchases of large household items, property, and businesses. The internment was immensely disruptive to businesses and farm operations, but the bulk of the letters requesting guidance indicated an attempt to cooperate as much as possible within a very short time frame. Internees were told to take only what they could carry, but this was not enough, as the winters were cold. People with small children, elderly people, invalids, could not bring enough with them and wrote to request exemptions or direction. Several interned families had sons or husbands who were serving in the US military at the time. Some were married to Caucasians, or were of mixed parentage. Non-Japanese farmers also suffered, as their supply of farm labor plunged. Some of the early internees packed up and got ready to go before they were called, and there was a certain amount of confusion at the beginning when buildings for furniture storage, internment camps, and other parts of the operation had not yet been set up. Over the months of March, April, and May, families were assigned numbers and interviewed at several locations in Oregon. For each family, an information sheet was filled out, listing family name, address, possessions and properties needing to be stored or disposed of, and recording the suggestions made and/or the decisions reached. In early May, General DeWitt, who was headquartered at the Western Defense Command and Fourth Army at the Presidio of San Francisco, issued numbered Civilian Exclusion Orders, indicating which Oregon counties needed to be evacuated by which date. These orders specified what the families could take with them to their Assembly Centers: 1. 2. 3. 4. Bedding and linens (but no mattress) for each member of the family Toilet articles for each member of the family Extra clothing for each member of the family Sufficient knives, forks, spoons, plates, bowls and cups for each member of the family 5. Essential personal effects for each member of the family The Evacuee Property Department then sent individual letters (form WCCA FRB-2) to each family, telling what the family had listed as having been sent for storage and noting discrepancies between those lists and what was actually received. The families were asked to sign and date these inventories and return them. By the time these transactions were recorded, the families had already been transferred to their Assembly Centers. Many of the properties and possessions (homes, hotels, businesses, automobiles) were put on the market for sale. The Portland branch kept files of applicants who wanted to purchase or lease these goods and properties. However, in most cases applicants were referred to the families or were told they would be notified. The resolution was generally not indicated on these sheets. The document case (box 3) has the interview sheets, arranged by family number, taken at the Civil Control Station at the end of April and early May, 1942. These give the family name, number of members, citizenship, and a brief summary of what goods and properties needed to be stored and what arrangements were made. A few of these have key tags attached, but most of these tags indicate that there were no keys available. Some interview sheets are also at the end of box 2. * automobiles: “ the federal government would become directly responsible for this expropriation: for example, the U.S. Army bought Japanese Americans’ cars for token prices; after the Federal Reserve Bank promised to store cars, evacuees turned over about two thousand, only to learn later in 1942 that their cars had been requisitioned by the army. See John Hersey, ‘A Mistake of Terrifically Horrible Proportions,’ in John Armor and Peter Wright, Manzanar (New York: Times Books, 1988), 6.” Impounded, p. 26. However, there are records in this collection indicating that at least some of the car owners were paid by the Army. Container List Box 1 (39, i.e. 37, folders): 1.
